Environmental Issue/ Concern: New Pipeline in Alberta  Trench subsidence
Location: 2010 - Approx. 90 sites in 110 km section between;  Section 2-31-4-W4 and  Section 34-22-4-W4.  2011 – In addition to areas noted above, all land tracts were assessed in 2011
Current Status 2010: The total area within the 110 km section is approx. 1.8 ha. Typical areas are 20 m in length, 2-3 m wide and <0.3 m deep.
Current Status 2011: • Numerous site deficiencies were corrected by stripping back topsoil and feathering in subsoil, or if very small or possibly in pasture/ native range, acceptable topsoil sources are secured and used to fill-in trench subsidence.  • Sites were assessed with remediation completed on areas with potential to impact landowner and/ or pipeline operations.
Current Status 2012: • Numerous areas (approx. 2500 m or 1.4 ha) were corrected by stripping back topsoil and feathering in subsoil, or if acceptable topsoil sources could be secured, topsoil was used to fill-in minor trench subsidence.  • Sites were assessed with remediation completed on areas with potential to impact landowner and/ or pipeline operations.
Current Status 2013: • Numerous areas (approx. 3500 m or 2.5 ha) were corrected by stripping back topsoil and feathering in subsoil, or if acceptable topsoil sources could be secured, topsoil was used to fill-in minor trench subsidence.  • Sites were assessed with remediation completed on areas with potential to impact landowner and/ or pipeline operations.
Current Status 2014: • Numerous areas (approx. 9100 m or 9.1 ha) were corrected, using combinations of stripping back topsoil and feathering in subsoil, or if acceptable topsoil sources could be secured, topsoil was used to fill-in minor trench subsidence.  • Sites were assessed with remediation completed on areas with potential to impact landowner and/ or pipeline operations.
Current Status 2015: • Approx. 450 m at 49 locations were corrected, using combinations of stripping back topsoil and feathering in subsoil, or if acceptable topsoil sources could be secured, topsoil was used to fill-in minor trench subsidence.  • Sites were assessed with remediation completed on areas with potential to impact landowner and/ or pipeline operations.

Environmental Issue/ Concern: New Pipeline in Manitoba  Drainage adjacent to MLV Carman 49+200
Current Status 2010: Work completed in November 2010 as part of Post-Construction Monitoring
Current Status 2011: • Due to landowner crop loss claim in regard to ineffective drainage around compound, additional land-levelling completed Fall 2011. • Fine-tuned drainage around compound.
Current Status 2012: • Monitored in 2012.  • Drainage around the MLV appears to be OK.
Current Status 2013: • Monitored in 2013.  • Fall of 2013 additional land-leveling to fine-tune drainage around valve compound.
Current Status 2015: • Site monitored throughout 2015 growing season.  • No drainage issues observed.
Recommendations/ Schedule for 2016: No further work or monitoring required.  PCEM is considered to be complete.

Environmental Issue/ Concern: New Pipeline in Manitoba Drainage within adjacent sections.
Current Status 2013: • Monitored in 2013.  • Fall of 2013 land-leveling in SE 11-2-5WPM to correct surface contours, restore 2 field drains, and restore elevation to a RM of Stanley trail. • Fall 2013 land-leveling in NE 11-2-5WPM to recapture /restore topsoil washouts and to restore elevation at windrow of trees.
Current Status 2015: • Site monitored throughout 2015 growing season.  • No drainage issues observed.
Recommendations/ Schedule for 2016: No further work or monitoring required.  PCEM is considered to be complete.

Environmental Issue/ Concern: New Pipeline in Manitoba  Potential land levelling
Location: Areas on numerous tracts. Sizes ranging from 5 m length to 200 m length, and 5 m wide to full width of right-of-way.
Current Status 2010: 2010 helicopter reconnaissance with video capability, some ground recon, as well as discussions with landowners noted inconsistencies in contours across the right-of-way. Land levelling completed in a few locations in 2010.
Current Status 2011: • Land-levelling completed on various land-tracts in 2011.  • 2011 assessments determined uneven field surface contours (high spots/low spots).  • Normal farm practices do not readily correct these inconsistencies.
Current Status 2012: • Land-levelling completed on various land-tracts in 2012.
Current Status 2013: • Land-levelling completed on various land-tracts in 2013.
Current Status 2014: • Land-levelling completed on 29 various land-tracts in 2014. • All areas on the New Pipeline in Manitoba segment completed in 2014.
Current Status 2015: • During the 2015 monitoring period as well as consultation with landowners, 10 out of the 29 tracts that were completed in 2014 required some fine tuning/ levelling to address minor drainage issues.
Recommendations/ Schedule for 2016: Monitor the 10 tracts in 2016, where levelling was conducted in 2015.

Environmental Issue/ Concern: New Pipeline in Alberta  Native Vegetation establishment
Current Status 2010: 2010 PCEM indicates very good native species germination and ground cover. Other than deficiency as noted in September 8, 2010 record, ground is fully stabilized.
Current Status 2011: • 2011 PCEM indicates very good native species germination and ground cover. Ground is fully stabilized.  • Deficiency as noted in September 8, 2010 record, indicates good native species germination and ground cover.
Current Status 2012: • 2012 PCEM indicates very good native species germination and ground cover. Ground is fully stabilized.
Current Status 2013: • 2013 PCEM indicates very good native species germination and ground cover. Ground is fully stabilized.
Current Status 2014: • 2014 PCEM indicates very good native species germination and ground cover. Ground is fully stabilized.
Current Status 2015: • Vegetation cover onsite 85-95% as compared to off RoW; moderate cattle grazing onsite, wire removed from fence along RoW.
Recommendations/ Schedule for 2016: No further work or monitoring required.  PCEM is considered to be complete.

Environmental Issue/ Concern: New Pipeline in Alberta  Shrub Planting
Current Status 2011: • Planted approximately 170 Manitoba Maple and Chokecherry on banks, completed in June 2011.
Current Status 2012: • Assessed area and determined that success was not adequate due to utilizing potted stock that was not mature enough for the site conditions. • Larger/ more mature potted stock (115 plants) was planted in June 2012 and monitored throughout the growing season, with much better success to date.
Current Status 2013: • Larger/ more mature potted stock (75 willow, maple and chokecherry plants) were planted in June 2013. • Assessed area and determined that success appears to be adequate at this time. • Livestock continue to have some affect when electric fencing is breached.
Current Status 2014: • 3 shrubs on the north side and 6 shrubs on the south side appear to be surviving from the planting in June 2013. • Livestock continue to have some affect when electric fencing is breached.
Current Status 2015: In additional to shrubs • noted in 2014, encroachment of native forbs and shrubs from the RoW boundaries. • Slopes are stable. • Minor erosion on the south bank as a result of livestock watering on the RoW. Gravel / cobble was placed in September 2015 to repair the erosion.
Recommendations/ Schedule for 2016: Monitor in 2016.  Assess at the appropriate time in the 2016 growing season to verify that the willow plantings are sufficient and providing a level of confidence that reclamation objectives are continuing to be successful.
